department: Art of Africa and the Americas
description: two images printed in color on one sheet; left image: barren landscape with roofless building and tall smokestack/tower; right image: reproduction of image of New York-New York casino and hotel in Las Vegas, with overly red and yellow sky and foreground; inherent vertical white rippling lines, especially at left side of image, on original image
medium: Digital inkjet print on Baryta paper
text: The Democratic Republic of Congo is “a geological scandal”—a country with one of the richest mineral deposits in the world, whose profits from excavation hardly benefit its population. Sammy Baloji photographs his native province of Katanga, a mineral-rich area that is home to artisanal mining on a huge scale. The tarpaulin homes of the miners are decorated with kitsch posters made in China, which depict images of Western or Asian cities, and real or touched-up landscapes that suggest a utopian world. By photographing the desolate mine landscapes of his homeland and pairing them with these idyllic scenes, Baloji creates an uncomfortable contrast.
title: Raccord #7, Usine de Shituru
